title:
Reformulating polarized radiative transfer for astrophysical
  applications (I). A formalism allowing non-local Magnus solutions

sections.text:
#### Abstract

The solar atmosphere is diagnosed by solving the polarized radiative transfer problem for plasmas in Non-Local Thermodynamic Equilibrium (NLTE). A key challenge in multidimensional NLTE diagnosis is to integrate efficiently the radiative transfer equation (RTE), but current methods are local, i.e. limited to constant propagation matrices. This paper introduces a formalism for non-local integration of the RTE using the Magnus expansion. We begin by framing the problem in terms of rotations within the Lorentz / Poincaré group (Stokes formalism), motivating the use of the Magnus expansion. By combining the latter with a highly detailed algebraic characterization of the propagation matrix, we derive a compact analytical evolution operator that supports arbitrary variations of the propagation matrix and allows to increasingly consider any order in the Magnus expansion. Additionally, we also reformulate the inhomogeneous part of the RTE, again using the Magnus expansion, and introducing the new concept of inhomogeneous evolution operator. This provides the first consistent, general, and non-local formal solution to the RTE that is furthermore efficient and separates integration from the algebraic formal solution. Our framework is verified analytically and computationally, leading to a new family of numerical radiative transfer methods and potential applications such as accelerating NLTE calculations. With minor adjustments, our results apply to other universal physical problems sharing the Lorentz / Poincaré algebra in special relativity and electromagnetism.


Subject headings: Sun: atmosphere, radiative transfer, polarization, magnetic fields, scattering

## 1. INTRODUCTION

As astrophysics studies distant plasmas through scattered light, it is crucial to model and measure precisely how polarized light behaves. Currently, the measurement and interpretation of Stokes spectropolarimetry in spectral lines is the best known way of diagnosing astrophysical plasmas (Stenflo 1994; Landi Degl'Innocenti \& Landolfi 2004, LL04 hereafter). Thus, the Stokes 4-vector describes any partially polarized light beam, quantifying both the number of photons and their oscillation direction within the beam's reference frame (Born \& Wolf 1980). Once quantified, the next step is to describe its transference through the emitter plasma using the polarized radiative transfer equation (RTE).
This key astrophysical problem is best studied in the nearby and well-resolved solar atmosphere, where most diagnostic techniques and methods have been developed. In such a context, radiative transfer is a fundamental part of the NonLocal Thermodynamic Equilibrium (NLTE) problem, in which radiation emitted at a given point in the solar atmosphere modifies, via radiative transfer, the physical state of other distant points. In Stokes formalism, the polarized RTE contains a $4 \times 4$ propagation matrix quantifying the microphysics through optical coefficients that depend on angle, wavelength, and distance along the ray. This makes the integration of the RTE the most frequent and critical operation carried out in NLTE iterative schemes, especially when considering multidimensional solar models or inversions of optically thick lines. One motivation for the present paper is to solve the RTE

[^0]with more robust and accurate methods whose properties are preserved when dealing with large velocity gradients as those above photospheric layers. Also, boosting efficiency is a must for NLTE diagnosis in the era of big-data solar telescopes like DKIST. However, all this implies pursuing a more fundamental goal, which we consider the next level in polarized radiative transfer. Specifically, we aim at solving the RTE consistently in spatially resolved solar models without assuming constant local properties.

The use of constant propagation matrices is a valid and universally adopted technique for solving the RTE. It has been used since Unno (1956) and Rachkovsky (1967) first derived the full polarized RTE including magnetic fields and magneto-optical effects in the propagation matrix, together with its first analytical solution, valid for Milne-Eddington (i.e., constant, spatially homogeneous) atmospheres. Later, van Ballegooijen (1985) and Landi Degl'Innocenti \& Landi Degl'Innocenti (1985) (hereafter vB85 and LD85; see also Kalkofen 2009) provided analytical evolution operators solving the homogeneous RTE, again with constant propagation matrix in Jones and Stokes formalisms, respectively.

However, there were soon evidences that spatial variations are not negligible in the solar atmosphere. On one hand, numerical solutions of the RTE were found to improve significantly when the atmosphere was subdivided into multiple layers (e.g., Rees et al. 1989; Bellot Rubio et al. 1998). On the other, numerical inversions of observed solar Stokes profiles confirmed the need for models with spatial variations (Collados et al. 1994; Del Toro Iniesta \& Ruiz Cobo 1996). Hence, many layers are needed both for models and numerical methods.


[^0]:    *E-mails: ecarlin@iac.es, e.carlin.mail@gmail.com

Initially, the inhomogeneous nature of the solar atmosphere was primarily attributed to large-scale stratification in density, temperature, and magnetic field. However, advances in both observations and simulations continue to demand ever-smaller resolved scales. Modern MHD solar models, for instance, still need finer resolution to address physical challenges like coronal and chromospheric heating (e.g., Leenaarts et al. 2009; Khomenko et al. 2018). Early simulations also revealed large velocity-driven inhomogeneities, especially in the chromosphere (e.g., Carlsson \& Stein 1997). Indeed, plasma velocity gradients in sound/shock waves are primary sources of solar small-scale variations and discontinuities, with a large and specific impact in the polarization via radiative transfer effects (Carlin et al. 2013), either due to their modulation of radiation field anisotropy (Carlin \& Asensio Ramos 2015) and/or due to a relatively new phenomenon that we may call dynamic dichroism (Carlin 2019).

To address spatial atmospheric variations in resolved atmospheres while using formalisms based on constant properties, numerical methods based on "ray characteristics" (e.g., Kunasz \& Auer 1988) were developed. Some representative methods using constant properties are the piecewise constant Evolution Operator method (vB85, LD85), the "DELO" methods (Rees et al. 1989) of linear, semi- parabolic, and parabolic kind (see Janett et al. 2017); or the order-3 DELO-Bezier (De la Cruz Rodríguez \& Piskunov 2013).

Hence, we face a seemingly paradoxical situation. Despite increasingly smaller spatial variations continue to be observed in the sun and needed to model its atmosphere, for over 65 years all mainstream numerical methods for solving the polarized RTE in (solar) astrophysics have remained limited to evolution operators with constant propagation matrices. These methods work very well as they asymptotically approach their regime of local constant properties but they have to solve the RTE at each numerical cell, i.e. sequentially and many times along every ray. This process scales with the increasing resolution of the models, becoming a main source of computational cost. Clearly, the idealization of constant properties is never fully achieved because radiative transfer depends on several atmospheric quantities with different sources of gradients and scales of variation. Moreover, it cannot be achieved simultaneously and uniformly for all wavelengths (e.g. around a spectral line) using a same discretization because the effective integration step of any numerical cell changes with wavelength (optical depth does it, and current methods integrate in optical depth scale). This fact is reinforced by the sensitivity of the optical depth step to Doppler shifts and opacity variations in the star.

This situation remarks the importance of the evolution operator, which as the matrix that advances the solution of a differential equation, fully characterizes the final solution physically and numerically (Gantmacher 1959). vB85 and LD85 recognized this when they introduced in (solar) astrophysics the evolution operator method to solve the RTE. It is based on approximating the homogeneous evolution operator analytically by an exponential of a constant propagation matrix. To our knowledge, this method is currently used in solar physics only by the Hazel code (Asensio Ramos et al. 2008) mainly to synthesize the HeI $\lambda 10830$ line in optically thin conditions. Four reasons may explain this limited adoption: i) since it is piecewise constant, the method has low numerical order; ii) its evolution operator matrix is lengthy (spanning about a page) and lacks a clear physical interpretation; iii) its numerical implementation is not efficient; and iv) it exhibits a limiting oscillatory behavior for strong (optically-thick) spectral lines
with magneto-optical effects (e.g., Bellot Rubio et al. 1998). In this paper we solve the first three issues. We believe that the fourth one may actually stem from the formulation with constant properties, and in this paper we set a basis that allows to investigate it.

In summary, currently adopted methods are limited by numerical approximations based on local constant properties, so it is unrealistic to hope for the large performance boosts demanded by the general NLTE problem, which is non-local by definition. Here, we start exploring new general analytical solutions that also allow neat and fully consistent implementations of arbitrary spatial variations. The only previous attempt to solve this general problem was by Semel \& López Ariste (1999) and López Ariste \& Semel (1999)(hereafter SLA99 and LAS99). We think that LAS99's central intent, which is shared in the present paper, has a huge potential for solar diagnosis that was unfortunately overlooked by the solar community. LAS99 considered the group structure of the RTE and applied the Wei \& Norman (1963) method to formally pose a non-local solution based on products of matrix exponentials. However, their scheme only provided a semi-closed formulation demanding to solve some coupled differential equations for the optical coefficients under poorly specified conditions, which anticipated a lack of economy and refrained a numerical materialization. Without discarding such results, we present a different approach based on the Magnus expansion (Magnus 1954).

Enters the key problem of commutativity: when an atmosphere varies spatially, its propagation matrices do not commute between points, preventing exact solutions. SLA99 saw this as an intrinsic limitation of the complex noncommutative structure of the Magnus expansion. Thus, they avoided it explicitly, arguing (correctly) that without commuting layers the solution requires a constant propagation matrix that forces discretization. In our work, we shall assume spatial discretization and arbitrary spatial variations, fully accepting non-commutativity as an inherent part of the problem, and exploring how to incorporate it in the theory with the Magnus expansion. Among its remarkable aspects, this expansion retains intrinsic properties of the exact solution by preserving its group structure after truncation in the Lie algebra (e.g., Blanes et al. 2009). It is defined with a single exponential of integrals and commutators, which avoids products of matrix exponentials, differential formulations, and (intrinsically innaccurate) perturbative developments.

This first paper presents the analytical foundational part of our formalism: - Section 2 presents the problem in Stokes formalism, interpreting solutions to the RTE as rotations in a Lie group, and elaborating on the Magnus expansion. $\bullet$ Section 3 presents a detailed definition and characterization of the propagation vector and propagation matrix. $\bullet$ Section 4 derives a compact analytical evolution operator using Magnus to first order and delves into higher orders. $\bullet$ Section 5 derives a novel formal solution based on the new inhomogeneous evolution operator. -Section 6 demonstrates our formalism in a model solar atmosphere and advance some applications.

## 2. FOUNDATIONS: RADIATIVE TRANSFER IN TERMS OF ROTATIONS WITH THE MAGNUS EXPANSION
### 2.1. Generic solution in Stokes formalism

The polarized RTE is a system of four coupled firstorder, ordinary differential equations whose homogeneous / inhomogeneous term contains the propagation / emissivity

matrix / vector (e.g., LL04, chap. 8):

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{ds}} \mathbf{I}=\boldsymbol{\epsilon}-\mathbf{K I}
$$

with $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$ the emissivity vector and $\mathbf{K}$ the $4 \times 4$ propagation matrix:

$$
\frac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{ds}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
I \\
Q \\
U \\
V
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\epsilon_{I} \\
\epsilon_{Q} \\
\epsilon_{U} \\
\epsilon_{V}
\end{array}\right)-\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
\eta_{I} & \eta_{Q} & \eta_{U} & \eta_{V} \\
\eta_{Q} & \eta_{I} & \rho_{V} & -\rho_{U} \\
\eta_{U} & -\rho_{V} & \eta_{I} & \rho_{Q} \\
\eta_{V} & \rho_{U} & -\rho_{Q} & \eta_{I}
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
I \\
Q \\
U \\
V
\end{array}\right)
$$

The homogenous part is then posed as the initial value problem:

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{I}(s)}{d s}=-\mathbf{K}(s) \mathbf{I}(s) ; \quad \mathbf{I}\left(s_{0}\right)=\mathbf{I}_{0}
$$

whose homogeneous formal solution at $s$ is given by an evolution operator $\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{K}\right)$ applied to the initial value at $\mathrm{s}_{0}$

$$
\mathbf{I}(s)=\mathbf{O}\left(\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{~s}_{0} ; \mathbf{K}\right) \cdot \mathbf{I}\left(\mathrm{s}_{0}\right)
$$

with $\mathbf{O}\left(\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{s}_{0} ; \mathbf{K}\right)$ the solution to ${ }^{1}$

$$
\frac{d}{d s} \mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0}\right)=-\mathbf{K}(\mathrm{s}) \mathbf{O}\left(\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{~s}_{0}\right), \quad \mathbf{O}\left(\mathrm{s}_{0}, \mathrm{~s}_{0}\right)=\mathbb{1}
$$

Knowing this operator, the inhomogenous solution to Eq. (1) is

$$
\mathbf{I}(s)=\mathbf{O}\left(\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{~s}_{0}\right) \mathbf{I}\left(\mathrm{s}_{0}\right)+\int_{\mathrm{s}_{0}}^{\mathrm{s}} \mathrm{ds}^{\prime} \mathbf{O}\left(\mathrm{s}, \mathrm{~s}^{\prime}\right) \boldsymbol{\epsilon}\left(\mathrm{s}^{\prime}\right)
$$

The suitability of this formal solution is physically and numerically determined by the expressions adopted for the evolution operator and for the inhomogeneous integral. Our goal is to formulate them in the best possible way.

### 2.2. The currently adopted solution to the evolution operator is a series that cannot be truncated

Applying the fundamental theorem of calculus to Eq.(5), an evolution operator is obtained by Volterra (1887)'s integral equation with $\mathbf{A}=-\mathbf{K}$ :

$$
\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{A}\right)=\mathbb{1}+\int_{s_{0}}^{s} d t \mathbf{A}(t) \mathbf{O}\left(t, s_{0}, \mathbf{A}\right)
$$

A Picard iteration on Eq. (7) can continue with $\mathbf{O}\left(t, s_{0}, \mathbf{A}\right)=$ $\mathbb{1}$ and repeated infinitely. Thus, a more accurate expression was obtained by Peano (1888) (also Peano (1890), translated in Kannenberg (2000)) and further studied by Baker (1902, 1905). It is the Peano-Baker series:
$\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{A}\right)=\mathbb{1}+\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \mathbf{A}(t) d t+\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \mathbf{A}\left(t_{1}\right) \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{1}} \mathbf{A}\left(t_{2}\right) d t_{2} d t_{1}+\cdots$
This series is unique and converges absolutely and uniformly in every closed interval where $\mathbf{A}$ is continuous and bounded (Ince 1956; Gantmacher 1959). It is applied in different contexts, most often known as the Neumann series or the Dyson perturbative solution (Dyson 1949) and simplified for constant A. In our case, if $\mathbf{A}=-\mathbf{K}=c t$., Eq. (8) becomes:

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=\mathbb{1}+\mathbf{A}\left(s-s_{0}\right)+\cdots+\frac{\mathbf{A}^{n}\left(s-s_{0}\right)^{n}}{n!}+\cdots=e^{-\mathbf{K}\left(s-s_{0}\right)}
$$

We shall see that the problem with solutions (8) and (9) is that in general any truncation -also in numerical exponentiation-

[^0]makes them to leave the Lie group of the differential equation, no longer preserving the physical properties of the exact solution (Blanes et al. 2009).

In astrophysics, the Dyson solution for the Stokes RTE was specified for $\mathbf{K}=c t$. by LL04 in two steps. Starting from Eq. (8):

$$
\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0}\right)=\mathbb{1}+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(-1)^{n} \int_{s_{0}}^{s} d s_{1} \cdots \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{n-1}} d s_{n} \mathbf{K}\left(s_{1}\right) \cdots \mathbf{K}\left(s_{n}\right)
$$

and making the integration regions independent on integration variables, one obtains the "time-ordered" exponential in terms of the Dyson chronological ${ }^{2}$ product of operators $\mathcal{P}$ (Step 1):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0}\right) & =\mathbb{1}+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!} \int_{s_{0}}^{s} d s_{1} \cdots \int_{s_{0}}^{s} d s_{n} \mathcal{P}\left\{\mathbf{K}\left(s_{1}\right) \cdots \mathbf{K}\left(s_{n}\right)\right\}= \\
& =\mathcal{P}\left\{e^{-\int_{s_{0}}^{s} d t \mathbf{K}(\mathbf{t})}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\mathcal{P}\left\{\mathbf{K}\left(s_{1}\right) \mathbf{K}\left(s_{2}\right) \cdots \mathbf{K}\left(s_{n}\right)\right\}=\mathbf{K}\left(s_{j_{1}}\right) \mathbf{K}\left(s_{j_{2}}\right) \cdots \mathbf{K}\left(s_{j_{n}}\right)$ for $s_{j_{1}} \leq s_{j_{2}} \leq \cdots \leq s_{j_{n}}$. The ordered exponential becomes an ordinary one when the ordered products commute among all of them $\left(\left[\mathbf{K}\left(s_{i}\right), \mathbf{K}\left(s_{j}\right)\right]=0\right)$, such that can be reordered. Only then, they become ordinary products of a single integral, leading to the Taylor expansion of its exponential (Step 2):

$$
\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0}\right)=\mathbb{1}+\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!}\left[\int_{s_{0}}^{s} d t \mathbf{K}(t)\right]^{n}=e^{-\int_{s_{0}}^{s} d t \mathbf{K}(t)}=e^{-\mathbf{K} \cdot \Delta s}
$$

We added the last equality to remark that, if commutation is assumed, the exponent is immediately forced to be calculated with $\mathbf{K}$ constant, a restrictive situation that is systematically adopted in applications. Indeed, as it is imposible that propagation matrices commute simultaneously for all rays inside a realistic atmosphere, the only plausible assumption to achieve commutation is to restrict them to be constant along each integration step. Apart from the obvious fact that atmospheres are not constant at small scales, this raises at least two sources of error. The first one comes from solutions assuming $\mathbf{K}$ constant but emissivity changing in the inhomogeneous integral. A fully consistent solution for $\mathbf{K}$ constant would then imply constant emissivity because their physical dependences are such that one cannot change if the other is constant (inconsistency). A second issue is the computation of the exponential and of the terms mimicking the inhomogeneous integral in the numerical method. Such operations can imply indirect truncation of the Dyson series and damage to the matrix symmetry of the effective evolution operator (also inside the inhomogeneous solution), and therefore a systematic hidden error built in the numerical implementation (innacuracy). Other way to say this is that solutions do not evolve in the Lie group corresponding to the RTE. This restricts methods to be "local", i.e. to discrete numerical cells with constant properties. Hence, the price that methods pay to compensate that combination of errors is the need to be applied cell by cell (locally), whose cost roughly scales with the resolution of the numerical grid (inneficiency).

Our goal is to design an alternative accurate formalism that respects the Lie structure of the RTE and that is general enough to incorporate spatial inhomogeneity and non-locality.

### 2.3. Radiative transfer solutions as rotations in a Lie group

Our first step is interpreting the evolution of the radiative transfer solution in terms of rotations in a Lie group. To start, consider that, for natural light, $I^{2}>Q^{2}+U^{2}+V^{2}$, which maps a Stokes vector to a point inside the three-dimensional Poincaré sphere $Q / I, U / I, V / I$ (e.g., Shurcliff 2013). Similarly, solutions at each location along the ray are now seen as points forming a differentiable manifold $\mathcal{M}$ in a 4D Poincaré space mapping each dimension to a Stokes parameter (Fig. 2). In this scenario, the evolution operator $\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{A}\right)$ is a Lorentz-Poincaré group element called flow of $\mathbf{A}$ because it follows $\mathbf{A}$ to advance the homogeneous solution from $\boldsymbol{I}\left(s_{0}\right)$ to $\boldsymbol{I}(s)$ in $\mathcal{M}$ (see Eq. (4)). Let us see now this advance as a rotation, $\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{A}\right)$ being a rotation matrix. Then, with Eq. (5) (or (8)), $\mathbf{A}$ is seen as a vector field tangent to the s-parametric streamline $\boldsymbol{I}\left(s_{0}\right) \rightarrow \boldsymbol{I}(s)$. I.e., $\mathbf{A}$ is ${ }^{3}$ the derivative of the flow at $s=s_{0}$ :

$$
\mathbf{A}=-\mathbf{K}=\left.\frac{d \mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{A}\right)}{d s}\right|_{s=s_{0}}
$$

This gives a local coordinate map linking $\mathcal{M}$ and its tangent linear space $\mathcal{T}_{P}$, formed by all possible tangent vector fields $\mathbf{A}$ at the group identity $\mathcal{P}$, i.e., where $\mathbf{O}\left(s, s_{0} ; \mathbf{A}\right)=\mathbb{1}$ for $s=s_{0}$. This condition is satisfied when $\mathbf{O}$ is an exponential map. More precisely, the link is between $\mathcal{M}$ and its Lie algebra ( $\mathfrak{g}$ ), which is defined as $\mathcal{T}_{P}$ with the operation of commutation. Thus, at $\mathcal{P}$ the group structure is locally captured by its algebra, a simpler object (vector space). The mapping also allows solving the problem in $\mathcal{T}_{P}$ (the Magnus expansion being the full solution). Indeed, commutators of $\mathbf{A}$ among points along the ray shall appear in the Magnus expansion to represent the total derivative of the vector field $\mathbf{A}$. Such non-linear combination of fields gears a non-local evolution from $\mathfrak{g}$, as if it was an ocean of small eddies or currents under the large-scale surface of the group.

Again, further exponentiation converts that advance into a resultant rotation connecting two points in the group. Figure 1 illustrates a particular example of this for the RTE in Stokes formalism. It also shows the key idea introduced before: to preserve the qualitative properties of the exact solution (e.g., the geometric shape of the rotation), we need analytical and numerical solutions respecting the group structure of the RTE. A detailed analysis of the propagation matrix in the LorentzPoincaré group associated to the RTE is presented in Sec. 3.2.

[^0]![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Fsc. 2.- Local homogeneous solutions (white circles) to the RTE evolving in the ordinary 3D space of the ray (orange) and in the 4D space of the Poincaré group (red). They result of locally applying the exponential map to linear vector fields (blue) in the Lie algebra.

The framework based on rotations and groups helps to understand the Magnus expansion and to work with it. It also suggests that more efficient rotation representations may exist for evaluating the expansion. Table 2.3 below summarizes some algebraic structures for representing rotations in threedimensional and Minkowski (Poincaré) spaces.

In general, the Jones formalism - which uses tensors and spinorial matrices to quantify polarization and its propagation - offers an alternative to the Stokes formalism. But currently, astrophysical radiative transfer is based on Stokes formalism since the Jones formalism, though equivalent, was shown not to be specially advantageous (Sanchez Almeida 1992). However, it is possible that expressing the Magnus expansion in other representations could yield an advantage (e.g., eliminating redundant operations with $4 \times 4$ matrices), which suggests a revision of this topic. While rotations are often represented by groups mapping onto (propagation) matrices that act on a vector space, matrices are not even the only possible representation. This should be discussed once the applicability of the Magnus expansion is demonstrated in Stokes formalism.

### 2.4. Magnus solution: an exact Lie-friendly evolution operator

Instead of solving Eq. (5) in its Lie group with (8), Hausdorff (1906) did it in its algebra (g) by assuming a single exponential for ${ }^{k} \mathbf{O}=e^{\mathbf{i} \mathbf{k}(s)}$. From $(\mathbf{A}=-\mathbf{K}$ in our case)

$$
\frac{d \mathbf{O}}{d s}=\mathbf{A O} \quad \Rightarrow \quad\left(\frac{d e^{\mathbf{i} \mathbf{k}(s)}}{d s}\right) e^{-\mathbf{\Omega}(s)}=\mathbf{A}
$$

he derived the non-linear differential Hausdorff equation for $\boldsymbol{\Omega}$ :

$$
\frac{d \boldsymbol{\Omega}}{d s}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{B_{n}}{n!}\left[\mathbf{A}, \boldsymbol{\Omega}^{|n|}\right]
$$

where $\left[\mathbf{A}, \boldsymbol{\Omega}^{|n|}\right]=\left[\cdots\{[\mathbf{A}, \boldsymbol{\Omega}], \boldsymbol{\Omega}\} \cdots, \boldsymbol{\Omega}\right]$ is an n-times rightnested commutator with $\left[\mathbf{A}, \boldsymbol{\Omega}^{|0|}\right]=\mathbf{A}$; and the $B_{n}$ are the Bernoulli numbers ${ }^{5}$. Remarkably, the series in Eq. (13) is the matricial form of the generating scalar function (see Sec. 5.1):

$$
\frac{x}{e^{x}-1}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{B_{n}}{n!} x^{n}
$$

The infinite recursive series in Eq. (13) is analytic in all $\mathbb{C}$ except in the points $\mathbb{P}=\{2 \pi n i, n \in \mathbb{Z}>0\}$. Iteration on Eq. (13) led Magnus (1954) to his expansion $\boldsymbol{\Omega}(s)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \boldsymbol{\Omega}_{n}(s)$ :

$$

with $\boldsymbol{\Omega}(0)=\mathbf{0}, d_{i}=d s_{i}$ and $\mathbf{A}_{i}=\mathbf{A}\left(s_{i}\right)$. The series converges in the neighbourhood of $\exp \left(\boldsymbol{\Omega}\left(s_{0}\right)\right)$ if the differences between any two eigenvalues of $\boldsymbol{\Omega}\left(s_{0}\right)$ is not in $\mathbb{P}$. Hence, $\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{2}$ are special, not only being the simplest terms, but also the only ones requiring only one term to fully quantify their respectives orders, a property that remains invariant irrespective of any formulation of the expansion.

\end{aligned}
$$

### 2.5. The Basic Evolution (BE) operator

The simplest evolution operator results of truncating ${ }^{8}$ the Magnus expansion to keep only its first term, which only contains the integral of $\mathbf{A}$. This is better than using Eq.(10) as

[^0]evolution operator, because the integral consistently preserves memory of the variation of the propagation matrix along the ray. Also note that all higher-order terms start by the same integral, so the whole expansion can be understood as a single integral of $\mathbf{A}$ plus corrections to $\mathbf{A}$. Then, let us now define a basic evolution operator as the matrix exponential of the integral of a propagation matrix.

Consider a matrix $\mathbf{M}=f \vec{a} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}$ that can be decomposed in terms of a constant $f$, a vector $\vec{a}=\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right)$ with module $a$, and a vector $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}=\left(\mathbf{B}_{1}, \mathbf{B}_{2}, \mathbf{B}_{3}\right)$ of basis matrices in algebra $\mathfrak{a}$ :

$$
\sigma_{i} \cdot \sigma_{j}=\delta_{i j} \mathbb{1}+c \cdot \epsilon_{i j k} \cdot \sigma_{k}, \quad(c=\text { constant })
$$

with $\epsilon_{i j k}$ the Levi-Civita permutation symbol ${ }^{9}$. Then, the exact exponential of the integral of $\mathbf{M}$ is (Appendix C):

$$
e^{ \pm \int d s \vec{a}^{\prime}(s) \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}}=\operatorname{ch}(b) \mathbb{1} \pm \operatorname{sh}(b) \vec{a} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}
$$

with $\vec{a}$ a unitary vector resulting of integrating $\vec{a}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\vec{u} & =\frac{\vec{b}}{b}=\frac{\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right)}{\left[b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+b_{3}^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}} \\
b_{k} & =\int d s a_{k}(s)
\end{aligned}
$$

Interpreting this in terms of rotations, we identify Eq. (21) as a rotor, an element of Clifford geometric algebra (Hestenes 2003) representing here a three-dimensional rotation around the axis $\vec{u}$.

The easiest example is to particularize to $\mathrm{SU}(2)$ representation, whose algebra basis are $2 \times 2$ Pauli matrices (table 2.3):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{\int d s \vec{a} \cdot \vec{\rho}}=\operatorname{ch}(\theta) \mathbb{1}+\operatorname{sh}(\theta) \vec{a} \cdot \vec{\sigma}= \\
= & \left(\begin{array}{ll}
\operatorname{ch}(\theta)+\operatorname{sh}(\theta) u_{1} & \operatorname{sh}(\theta)\left(u_{2}-i u_{3}\right) \\
\operatorname{sh}(\theta)\left(u_{2}+i u_{3}\right) & \operatorname{ch}(\theta)-\operatorname{sh}(\theta) u_{1}
\end{array}\right) \quad \in \operatorname{SU}(2)
\end{aligned}
$$

This matrix describes an evolution as hyperbolic rotations by an angle $\theta \equiv b$ in a plane with normal unit vector $\vec{u} \in \mathbb{R}^{3}$. Particularizing to $\mathbf{M}$ constant, $b_{k}=s \cdot a_{k}, b=s \cdot a$, and $\vec{u}=$ $\vec{a} / a$, which gives the rotation used in quantum mechanics to quantify the spin operator. It is composed of three independent two-dimensional rotations, one per plane perpendicular to a cartesian basis axes ${ }^{10}$. In the case of the polarization, the role of the axis of rotation is played by the propagation vector, which is defined in the next section and contains all the physical information of the propagation matrix that is necessary to rotate a vector in the QUV Poincaré space.

3.2. Algebraic characterization of the propagation matrix

This section characterizes the Lie group and algebra of the RTE, which is useful to operate with the Magnus expansion. Readers uninterested in these technical details may skip to the next section; relevant results will be referenced as needed.

SLA99 and LAS99 showed that the Stokes 4-vector can be seen as an element of a Minkowski-like $\mathbb{R}^{1,3}$ space, with $I$ as the temporal dimension. Thus, the RTE describes infinitesimal transformations within the "Stokes cone of light", categorized into 11 types forming a Poincaré group (the inhomogeneous generalization of a Lorentz group) allowing dilatations. The inhomogeneous term $(\epsilon)$ in the RTE accounts for four-dimensional translations, while dilatations appear from the diagonal of the propagation matrix in Eq. (2):

$$
\mathbf{K}(s)=\eta_{0}(s) \mathbb{1}+\hat{\mathbb{L}}(s)
$$

which reduces/amplifies the number of reemitted photons through indiscriminate positive/negative absorption of photons in any polarization states as of $\eta_{0}=\eta_{0}^{(\mathrm{A})}-\eta_{0}^{(\mathrm{S})}$ is dominated by ordinary absorption $\left(\eta_{0}^{(A)}\right)$ as in the sun, or by stimulated emission $\left(\eta_{0}^{(S)}\right)$. The remaining (homogeneous) part of the Poincaré group is the Lorentz group ${ }^{11} \mathrm{SO}(1,3)$, whose elements $\mathbf{O}$ can be expressed as exponentials of the Lorentz matrix $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$, accomplishing (Table 2.3; $\boldsymbol{J}=\operatorname{diag}(1,-1,-1,-1)$ ):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{O}^{T} \mathbf{J O}=\boldsymbol{J} \\
& \hat{\mathbb{L}}^{T} \boldsymbol{J}+\boldsymbol{J} \hat{\mathbb{L}}=0
\end{aligned}
$$

In turn, $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$ is composed of the 6 infinitesimal generators of rotations of the Lorentz group, i.e. the three $4 \times 4$ matrices $\hat{\mathbf{G}}_{1}, \hat{\mathbf{G}}_{2}, \hat{\mathbf{G}}_{3}$ generating ordinary 3D rotations (anomalous dispersion) in the QUV space, plus the three $4 \times 4$ matrices $\hat{\mathbf{G}}_{1}, \hat{\mathbf{G}}_{2}, \hat{\mathbf{G}}_{3}$ producing hyperbolic rotations (i.e., involving the first dimension) by dichroism (Lorentz boosts in relativity).

Our characterization of the propagation matrix is based on analyzing $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$ in four algebraic levels decomposing it in: 1) individual Lorentz generators; 2) base matrices; 3) hyperbolic and circular subspaces; and 4) complex Lorentz matrices. In the first level, the Lorentz generators are encoded in $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$ as ${ }^{12}$ :

$$

& =\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
\boldsymbol{\sigma} & 1 & \bigcirc & 1 \\
1 & 0 & 1 & \bigcirc \\
1 & 0 & 1 & \bigcirc \\
\hdashline 1 & \hdashline 1 & 0 & 1 \\
\hdashline 1 & \hdashline 1 & 1 & 0

$$

We also introduce a set of dual generators:

$$

Every generator $\hat{\mathbf{G}}_{k}, \hat{\mathbf{G}}_{k}, \hat{\mathbf{D}}_{k}, \hat{\mathbf{D}}_{k}$ is a $4 \times 4$ matrix describing rotations in a subspace whose only entries different than zero correspond to the pictoric symbols. For all $k$, we find:

where $\mathbb{1}_{k}=\operatorname{diag}\left(1, \delta_{1, k}, \delta_{2, k}, \delta_{3, k}\right\}$. Equivalently, all the above implies $\left(\hat{\mathbf{G}}_{k} \pm i \hat{\mathbf{G}}_{k}\right)^{2}=\mathbb{1}$. $$

Remarkably, any power $n \in \mathbb{Z}$ of $\mathbf{H}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ can be reduced to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{H}^{2 n}=\eta^{2(n-1)} \mathbf{H}^{2} \quad ; \quad \mathbf{H}^{2 n+1}=\eta^{2 n} \mathbf{H} \\
& \mathbf{R}^{2 n}=(-1)^{n-1} \rho^{2(n-1)} \mathbf{R}^{2} \quad ; \quad \mathbf{R}^{2 n+1}=(-1)^{n} \rho^{2 n} \mathbf{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

which allows to use power series to calculate exactly any function of $\mathbf{H}$ or $\mathbf{R}$ in terms of only $\mathbf{H}, \mathbf{R}, \mathbf{H}^{2}, \mathbf{R}^{2}$, where $\mathbf{H}^{2}, \mathbf{R}^{2}$ are easily obtained with

$$
\mathbf{H}^{2}=\mathbf{C}(\vec{\eta}) \quad ; \quad \mathbf{R}^{2}=\mathbf{C}(\vec{\rho})-\rho^{2} \mathbb{1}
$$

and $\mathbf{C}$ is the generic correlation matrix defined as:

$$
\mathbf{C}(\vec{u})=\left(\begin{array}{cccc}
u^{2} & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & u_{1}^{2} & u_{1} u_{2} & u_{1} u_{3} \\
0 & u_{1} u_{2} & u_{2}^{2} & u_{2} u_{3} \\
0 & u_{1} u_{3} & u_{2} u_{3} & u_{3}^{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

We also find interesting that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{H R H} & =\mathbf{R H R}=(\mathbf{H R})^{n}=(\mathbf{R H})^{n}=\mathbf{0} \quad(n \in \mathbb{Z}) \\
& -\mathbf{Q}^{T}=\mathbf{R H}=\left(\begin{array}{llll}
0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
S_{1} & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
S_{2} & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
S_{3} & 0 & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for $\mathbf{Q}=\mathbf{H R}$ and $\vec{S}=\vec{\eta} \times \vec{\rho}$. And as $\mathbf{H}$ and $\mathbf{R}$ do not commute:

$$
\begin{array}{ll}
{\left[\mathbf{H}_{i}, \mathbf{R}_{j}\right]=\mathbf{Q}+\mathbf{Q}^{T}=-\left(\vec{\eta}_{i} \times \vec{\rho}_{j}^{*}\right) \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}}} & (\mathbf{H}-\text { like }) \\
{\left[\mathbf{H}_{i}, \mathbf{H}_{j}\right]=\left(\vec{\eta}_{i} \times \vec{\eta}_{j}^{*}\right) \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}}} & (\mathbf{R}-\text { like }) \\
{\left[\mathbf{R}_{i}, \mathbf{R}_{j}\right]=-\left(\vec{\rho}_{i} \times \vec{\rho}_{j}^{*}\right) \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}}} & (\mathbf{R}-\text { like } \\
{\left[\ldots\left[\left[\mathbf{H}_{1}, \mathbf{R}_{1}\right], \mathbf{R}_{2}\right] \ldots, \mathbf{R}_{n}\right]=} & \\
=(-1)^{n}\left(\ldots\left(\left(\vec{\eta}_{1}^{*} \times \vec{\rho}_{1}^{*}\right) \times \vec{\rho}_{2}^{*}\right) \times \ldots \times \vec{\rho}_{n}^{*}\right) \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}} & (\mathbf{H}-\text { like })
\end{array}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\ldots\left[\left[\mathbf{H}_{0}, \mathbf{H}_{1}\right], \mathbf{H}_{2}\right] \ldots, \mathbf{H}_{n}\right]=} \\
& =(\ldots\left(\left(\vec{\eta}_{0}^{*} \times \vec{\eta}_{1}^{*}\right) \times \vec{\eta}_{2}^{*}\right) \times \ldots \times \vec{\eta}_{n}^{*}) \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}} \quad(\mathbf{R}-\text { like })
\end{aligned}
$$

These commutators may be useful to operate with the terms of the Magnus expansion. The third algebraic level arises decomposing in basis matrices. In terms of generators, we define a basis with $\mathbf{B}_{0}=\mathbb{1}$ and:

$$
\mathbf{B}_{k}=\tilde{\mathbf{G}}_{k}-i \tilde{\mathbf{G}}_{k} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}=\left(\mathbf{B}_{1}, \mathbf{B}_{2}, \mathbf{B}_{3}\right)
$$

for $k=1,2,3$. Then, we find for any $i, j>0$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbf{B}_{i} \mathbf{B}_{j}=\delta_{i j} \mathbb{1}+i \epsilon_{i j k} \mathbf{B}_{k}=\frac{\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}\right]_{+}+\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}\right]}{2} \\
& \mathbf{B}_{i}^{*} \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}=\delta_{i j} \mathbb{1}-i \epsilon_{i j k} \mathbf{B}_{k}^{*}=\frac{\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}^{*}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right]_{+}+\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}^{*}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right]}{2} \\
& \mathbf{B}_{k} \cdot \mathbf{B}_{k}^{*}=\mathbb{1}+2 \tilde{\mathbf{G}}_{k}^{2}=\mathbb{1} \mathbb{1}_{k}-\mathbb{1} \quad(\forall k) \\
& {\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right]=\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}^{*}, \mathbf{B}_{j}\right]=0} \\
& {\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}\right]=2 i \epsilon_{i j k} \mathbf{B}_{k} \quad \Rightarrow \quad\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}^{*}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right]=-2 i \epsilon_{i j k} \mathbf{B}_{k}^{*}} \\
& {\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}\right]_{+}=2 \delta_{i j} \mathbb{1}} \\
& {\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right]_{+}=2\left|\epsilon_{i j k}\right| \tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{k}+2 i \epsilon_{i j k}(-1)^{k} \tilde{\mathbf{D}}_{k}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The vector of matrices in (42) leads to a fourth algebraic level involving the propagation vector. Here, we propose the existence of a generalized (complex) Lorentz matrix:

$$
\mathbb{L}=\vec{a} \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}=\check{\mathbb{L}}+i \check{\mathbb{L}}
$$

Its real part is the ordinary Lorentz matrix $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ in Eq. (29), while the imaginary part is a new dual Lorentz matrix containing the same physical information as $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ but reorganized such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \check{\mathbb{L}}=(\vec{\eta} \cdot \vec{\rho}) \check{\mathbb{L}}^{-1} \\
& \check{\mathbb{L}}=\frac{\check{\mathbb{L}}+\mathbb{L}^{*}}{2}=\vec{\eta} \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{G}}+\vec{\rho} \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{G}} \\
& i \check{\mathbb{L}}=\frac{\mathbb{L}-\mathbb{L}^{*}}{2}=i(\vec{\rho} \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{G}}-\vec{\eta} \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{G}}) \\
& {\left[\mathbb{L}, \mathbb{L}^{*}\right]=[\check{\mathbb{L}}, \check{\mathbb{L}}]=0}
\end{aligned}
$$

These expressions are verified with a direct calculation. They show that $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ and $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ can be decomposed either with noncommuting Lorentz generators or with $\mathbb{L}$ and $\mathbb{L}^{*}$, which commute locally. Note also that $\check{\mathbb{L}}^{-1}$ (Eq. 45a) can be easily calculated by rearranging elements in $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ (Eq. 45b) to obtain $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ (Eq. 45c) and dividing by a scalar $\vec{\eta} \cdot \vec{\rho}$. Let us remind that the stardard formula for $\check{\mathbb{L}}^{-1}$ diverges when $|\check{\mathbb{L}}|=0$. The determinant of a matrix is the product of all its eigenvalues,
which for $\check{\mathbb{L}}$ and $\mathbf{K}$ are given by the sets

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \lambda_{1,2,3,4}^{\prime}=\left\{ \pm|\tilde{a}|, \pm i|\tilde{a}|\right\} \\
& \lambda_{1,2,3,4}=\left\{\eta_{0} \pm|\tilde{a}|, \eta_{0} \pm i|\tilde{a}|\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

containing the components of $a_{\pm}$(see Eq. 27). Multiplying all values in each set, we obtain the determinants:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& |\check{\mathbb{L}}|=|\check{\mathbb{L}}|=-p^{2} \\
& |\mathbf{K}|=\eta_{0}^{2}\left[\eta_{0}^{2}-r\right]+|\check{\mathbb{L}}| .
\end{aligned}
$$

with $p=\vec{\eta} \cdot \vec{\rho}$ and $r=\eta^{2}-\rho^{2}$ (Eqs. 28). Hence, standard $\check{\mathbb{L}}^{-1}$ diverges for ${ }^{1,2} p=0$, i.e. if $\eta$ or $\rho$ are zero ${ }^{14}$, or if $\vec{\eta} \perp \vec{\rho}$. This is not a problem in our formulation because, as said, Eq. (45a) gives a stable fast way of obtaining $\check{\mathbb{L}}^{-1}$ without divisions by zero, and because our solutions will not actually depend on $\check{\mathbb{L}}^{-1}$. This is not the case in piecewise-constant numerical methods such as the standard evolution operator.

Several key expressions arise from relating the basis and the Lorentz matrices. Using subscript $i$ for a quantity at point $s_{i}$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \check{\mathbb{L}}_{i}=\frac{\mathbb{L}+\mathbb{L}^{*}}{2}=\frac{\vec{a}_{i} \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}+\vec{a}_{i}^{*} \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*}}{2} \\
& {\left[\vec{a}_{1} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}, \vec{a}_{2} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}\right]=2 i\left(\vec{a}_{1} \times \vec{a}_{2}\right) \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}} \\
& {\left[\vec{a}_{1}^{*} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*}, \vec{a}_{2}^{*} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*}\right]=-2 i\left(\vec{a}_{1}^{*} \times \vec{a}_{2}^{*}\right) \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Besides, considering the normalized vector

$$
\vec{u}=\frac{\vec{a}}{a_{+}}=\frac{a_{-} \cdot \vec{u}}{h}=\frac{(\tilde{a}-\tilde{u}) \cdot \vec{a}}{h}
$$

it is direct to show that:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{u} \vec{B}=\frac{a_{-} \cdot \mathbb{L}}{h} \\
& \vec{u}^{*} \vec{B}^{*}=\frac{a_{+} \cdot \mathbb{L}^{*}}{h} \\
& \frac{\vec{u} \vec{B}+\vec{u}^{*} \vec{B}^{*}}{2}=\frac{\tilde{a} \vec{b}_{+}+\tilde{a} \vec{b}_{-}}{h} \\
& \frac{\vec{u} \vec{B}-\vec{u}^{*} \vec{B}^{*}}{2}=i \frac{\tilde{a} \vec{b}_{-}-\tilde{a} \vec{b}_{+}}{h} \\
& \left(\vec{u} \vec{B}\right) \cdot\left(\vec{u}^{*} \vec{B}^{*}\right)=\frac{\mathbb{L} \cdot \mathbb{L}^{*}}{h}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, using the commutation rules obtained, we discover:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \check{\mathbb{L}}^{2}-\check{\mathbb{L}}^{2}=r \cdot \mathbb{1} \\
& \mathbb{L}^{2}=a_{+}^{2} \mathbb{1} \quad ; \quad\left(\mathbb{L}^{*}\right)^{2}=a_{-}^{2} \mathbb{1} \\
& \frac{[\check{\mathbb{L}}, \check{\mathbb{L}}]_{+}}{2}=\check{\mathbb{L}} \cdot \check{\mathbb{L}}=i \frac{\left(\mathbb{L}^{2}-\left(\mathbb{L}^{*}\right)^{2}\right)}{4}=p \cdot \mathbb{1} \\
& \frac{\left[\mathbb{L}, \mathbb{L}^{*}\right]_{+}}{2}=\mathbb{L} \cdot \mathbb{L}^{*}=\check{\mathbb{L}}^{2}+\check{\mathbb{L}}^{2}=2 \mathbf{K}^{2}-4 \eta_{0} \mathbf{K}+\left(2 \eta_{0}^{2}-r\right) \mathbb{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

To obtain the last equality ${ }^{15}$ in Eq.(51d), we applied Eq. (51a) and $\check{\mathbb{L}}^{2}=\left(\mathbf{K}-\eta_{0} \mathbb{1}\right)^{2}=\mathbf{K}^{2}-2 \eta_{0} \mathbf{K}+\eta_{0}^{2} \mathbb{1}$. Using (51a) and (51c),

(37a) and (40b) gives same structure as $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$ :

\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{3}=\left[\eta^{2} \vec{\eta}+(\vec{S} \times \vec{\rho})\right] \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}}-\left[\rho^{2} \vec{\rho}+(\vec{S} \times \vec{\eta})\right] \cdot \overrightarrow{\tilde{\mathbf{G}}}

To obtain a neater expression for $\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}$, we combine Eqs. (54a) and (51d) into $\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbb{1}_{1} \mathbb{L}^{*}+r \mathbb{1}\right)$. Developing the summations in $\mathbb{L} \cdot \mathbb{L}^{*}$, we reach:

\mathbb{L} \cdot \mathbb{L}^{*}=2 \sum_{k}\left|a_{k}\right|^{2} \mathbb{1}_{k}-a^{2} \mathbb{1}+\sum_{k=1,2,3}\left(g_{k} \mathbf{D}_{k}+g_{k}^{*} \mathbf{D}_{k}^{*}\right)
$$

where $\mathbf{D}_{k}=\hat{\mathbf{D}}_{k}+i(-1)^{k} \hat{\mathbf{D}}_{k}$ are basis matrices obtained from dual generators and $g_{k}=a_{i} a_{j}^{*} \epsilon_{i j k}$ has coefficients cyclically ordered to give $\epsilon_{i j k}=1$. $$
\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}=\left(\mathbf{U}(a)-\rho^{2} \mathbb{1}\right)+\Re e\{\overrightarrow{g} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{D}}\}
$$

## 4. REFORMULATION OF THE HOMOGENEOUS SOLUTION
### 4.1. Derivation of the evolution operator for non-constant $\mathbf{K}$

To derive an evolution operator for arbitrary variations of $\mathbf{K}$, start truncating the Magnus expansion to first order in Eq. (19) and decompose $\hat{\mathbb{L}}(s)$ in generalized Lorentz matrices with Eq.(48a)

$$
\mathbf{O}(\mathrm{s})=\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2} \alpha \mathbf{K}(\mathrm{t})}=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau} \cdot \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\tau} \alpha \vec{a}(\mathrm{t}) \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}} \cdot \mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2} \int_{0}^{\tau} \alpha \vec{a}^{*}(\mathrm{t}) \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}}
$$

The commutation among $\mathbb{L}=\vec{a}(t) \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}$ and $\mathbb{L}^{*}$ in Eq. (45d) allows dividing the Magnus evolution operator in those two matrix exponentials. Yet, the exponents are integrals combining all points along the ray and there was the problem of commutativity, so let us be more specific. Calling $\vec{b}=\int_{b_{0}}^{b_{1}} d t \vec{a}(t)$, the two
matrix exponents can be joined as

$$
-\frac{1}{2}\left[\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}} \vec{b}+\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*} \vec{b}^{*}\right]
$$

because $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}$ is a vector of basis (i.e., constant) matrices. To split the two exponentials, any component of $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}} \vec{b}$ must commute with any other of $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*} \vec{b}^{*}$, which occurs due to Eq. (43d) because

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\mathbf{B}_{i} b_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*} b_{j}^{*}\right] } & =\left(b_{i} \mathbf{B}_{i}\right)\left(b_{j}^{*} \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right)-\left(b_{j}^{*} \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right)\left(b_{i} \mathbf{B}_{i}\right)= \\
& =b_{i} b_{j}^{*} \mathbf{B}_{i} \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}-b_{i} b_{j}^{*} \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*} \mathbf{B}_{i}=b_{i} b_{j}^{*}\left[\mathbf{B}_{i}, \mathbf{B}_{j}^{*}\right]=0
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we can apply the basic rotor Eq. (21) to each matrix exponential ${ }^{16}$ in Eq. (57), obtaining
$\mathbf{O}(\mathrm{s})=\mathrm{e}^{-\tau}\left[\operatorname{ch}\left(\frac{\mathrm{b}}{2}\right) \mathbb{1}-\operatorname{sh}\left(\frac{\mathrm{b}}{2}\right) \vec{a} \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}\right]\left[\operatorname{ch}\left(\frac{\mathrm{b}^{*}}{2}\right) \mathbb{1}-\operatorname{sh}\left(\frac{\mathrm{b}^{*}}{2}\right) \vec{a}^{*} \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{*}\right]$,
where $b$ and $\vec{a}$ cast $a_{+}$and $\vec{a} / a_{+}$in Sec. 3.1, but built from integrated coefficients $\eta_{k}^{i}$ and $\rho_{k}^{i}(k=1,2,3)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{a}=\frac{\vec{b}}{b}=\frac{\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right)}{\left[b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+b_{3}^{2}\right]^{1 / 2}}=\frac{(\hat{b}-i \hat{b})}{h}\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right) \\
& b_{k}(s)=\int_{s_{0}}^{s} a_{k}(t) d t=\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \eta_{k}(t) d t+i \int_{s_{0}}^{s} \rho_{k}(t) d t=\eta_{k}^{s}+i \rho_{k}^{s} \\
& \hat{b}^{2}=(h+r) / 2 \\
& \hat{b}^{2}=(h-r) / 2 \\
& h=\left[r^{2}+q^{2}\right]^{1 / 2} \quad\left(=\hat{b}^{2}+\hat{b}^{2}\right) \\
& r=\left(\vec{\eta}^{*}\right)^{2}-\left(\vec{\rho}^{*}\right)^{2} \quad\left(=\hat{b}^{2}-\hat{b}^{2}\right) \\
& q=2\left(\vec{\eta}^{*} \cdot \vec{\rho}^{*}\right) \quad(=2 \hat{b} \hat{b})
\end{aligned}
$$

This step allows to express everything in terms of the seven basic integrals $b_{k}$ as elementary coefficients. Next, we perform the products in Eq. (59), identify matrix terms with Eqs. (50), and apply Appendix D to separate the real $(\hat{b})$ and imaginary $(\hat{b})$ parts of $b$ and $b^{*}$. This leads to:

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=e^{-\tau} \cdot\left\{c_{0} \mathbb{1}-\frac{1}{h}\left[c_{1} \hat{\mathbb{L}}+c_{2} \hat{\mathbb{L}}+c_{3}\left(\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}+\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}\right)\right]\right\}
$$

with

$$
c_{0,3}=\frac{\operatorname{ch}(\hat{b}) \pm \cos (\hat{b})}{2} \quad ; c_{1,2}=\frac{\operatorname{sh}(\hat{b}) \mp i \sin (\hat{b})}{2}
$$

For simplicity we keep calling $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$ and $\hat{\mathbb{L}}$ as in previous sections, but hereafter they contain integrated coefficients. Finally, substituting Eq. (54a) for $\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}+\hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}$ and operating, we find

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=e^{-\tau} \cdot\left\{f_{0} \mathbb{1}+f_{1 a} \hat{\mathbb{L}}+f_{1 b} \hat{\mathbb{L}}+f_{2} \hat{\mathbb{L}}^{2}\right\}
$$

with scalar functions

$$
\begin{aligned}
& f_{0}=\frac{\hat{b}^{2} \operatorname{ch}(\hat{b})+\hat{b}^{2} \cos (\hat{b})}{\hat{b}^{2}+\hat{b}^{2}} \quad ; f_{1 a}=-\left[\frac{\hat{b} \operatorname{sh}(\hat{b})+\hat{b} \sin (\hat{b})}{\hat{b}^{2}+\hat{b}^{2}}\right] \\
& f_{2}=\frac{\operatorname{ch}(\hat{b})-\cos (\hat{b})}{\hat{b}^{2}+\hat{b}^{2}} \quad ; f_{1 b}=o \frac{\hat{b} \sin (\hat{b})-\hat{b} \operatorname{sh}(\hat{b})}{\hat{b}^{2}+\hat{b}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

${ }^{16}$ The conditions for Eq. (21) are fulfilled because the $\mathbf{B}_{k}$ matrices form a basis of the Lorentz algebra that accomplishes with Eq. (20) in Eq. (43a).

We calculate $\hat{b}$ and $\bar{b}$ from the positive root of their squares as in Eqs. $(60 \mathrm{~d}, \mathrm{e})$. Thereby, $\sigma=\operatorname{sign}(\vec{\eta} \cdot \vec{\rho})$ is added in $f_{1 b}$ for sign correction ${ }^{17}$.

Alternative expressions can be obtained using Eqs. (52) to substitute the $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ in Eq.(63) by a function of any odd power of $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$. For instance, in terms of $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ and $\vec{\mathbb{L}}^{3}$ with Eq. (52a), we obtain:

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=e^{-\tau} \cdot\left\{f_{0} \mathbb{1}+f_{1} \overrightarrow{\mathbb{L}}+f_{2} \overrightarrow{\mathbb{L}}^{2}+f_{3} \overrightarrow{\mathbb{L}}^{3}\right\}
$$

where the new functions are just

$$
f_{1}=-\left[\frac{\bar{b}^{2} \operatorname{sh}(\bar{b})+\bar{b}^{2} \sin (\bar{b})}{\bar{b}^{2}+\bar{b}^{2}}\right] ; f_{3}=-\left[\frac{\operatorname{sh}(\bar{b})}{\bar{b}}+\frac{\sin (\bar{b})}{\bar{b}}\right]
$$

The evolution operator can be made even more compact by dividing $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ and $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ into hyperbolic ( $\overrightarrow{\overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}}$ ) and rotational ( $\overrightarrow{\overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}}$ ) subspaces. Thus, operating, and regrouping, Eq. (63) becomes:

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=e^{-\tau} \cdot\left(\overrightarrow{\mathbf{K}}+f_{2} \overrightarrow{\mathbb{L}}^{2}\right)
$$

whose new matrix $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{K}}=f_{0} \mathbb{1}+\vec{\delta} \cdot \overrightarrow{\overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}}+\vec{\delta} \cdot \overrightarrow{\overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}}$ has same structure as $\mathbf{K}$ but with the new propagation vector

$$
\vec{\alpha}=\vec{\delta}+i \vec{\alpha}=-[\operatorname{sh}(\bar{b})+i \sin (\bar{b})] \vec{u}
$$

being $\vec{u}$ still given by Eq.(60a). Our three expressions for the evolution operator, Eqs. (63), (65), and (67), are fully equivalent. They all are more general and significantly simpler than the one given by LD85 for $\mathbf{K}$ constant. They are more general because, being exact exponentials of any propagation (Lorentz) matrix, they can still preserve memory of arbitrary spatial variations within the ray path integrals of optical coefficients, as defined in Eq.(60c), while also keeping their analytical form when higher order terms of the Magnus expansion are considered. They express everything in terms of seven basic scalar integrals ( $\tau$ and $b_{k}$ ), which seems to be the minimal and most efficient integration possible to solve the RTE for non-constant properties. This innovative separation between integration and algebraic calculation will also be present in the inhomogeneous solution.

The relative simplicity of our solution comes from expressing it in terms of the (integrated) Lorentz matrix $\vec{\mathbb{L}}=\mathbf{K}^{\prime}(s)-$ $\eta_{k}^{\prime}(s) \mathbb{1}=\vec{\eta}^{\prime} \cdot \overrightarrow{\vec{G}}+\vec{\rho}^{\prime} \cdot \overrightarrow{\vec{G}}$ and its dual $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$, which furthermore has a similar structure. Namely, from Eqs.(45), $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ is both $\propto \vec{\mathbb{L}}^{-1}$ and $\vec{\mathbb{L}}=\vec{\rho}^{\prime} \cdot \overrightarrow{\vec{G}}-\vec{\eta}^{\prime} \cdot \overrightarrow{\vec{G}}$, hence $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ and $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ are effortlessly built from each other by exchanging $\eta_{k}^{\prime} \leftrightarrow \rho_{k}^{\prime}$ and $\rho_{k}^{\prime} \leftrightarrow-\eta_{k}^{\prime}$.

Considering also that $\vec{\mathbb{L}}^{2}$ is directly calculated from $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ or by Eq.(56), we see that our homogenous solution is efficient. E.g., in Eq. (67) we just need to sum two composed matrices ( $\vec{\mathbb{L}}^{2}$ and $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{K}}$ ), half of them containing redundant (symmetric) information. Hence, our solution is analytically compact, efficient, and suitable for considering spatial variations of $\mathbf{K}$.

Eq. (67) reveals explicitly other insight: $\vec{\mathbb{L}}^{2}$ is the only term in the homogeneous solution whose structure differs from that of K. In other words, it is the only algebraic difference between an element of the Lorentz group (like the evolution operator) and one in its Lie algebra ( $\mathbf{K}$, or $\vec{\mathbb{L}}$ ). This shows why a numerical method calculating the exponential by truncating the Dyson

[^0]series Eq. (9) at an arbitrary power would be unsuitable, in general breaking the group structure.

Our result belongs to the Lorentz group because fulfills Eq. (30a). Particularizing Eq.(63) to zero dichroism $\left(\eta^{\prime}=0\right)$, then $q=\bar{b}=0, r=-h=\bar{b}^{2}=\left(\rho^{\prime}\right)^{2}, \vec{\mathbb{L}}=\mathbf{R}$ by Eq.(36), and substituting we obtain a Lorentz-Poincaré $4 \times 4$ generalization of the Rodrigues formula for rotations:

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=e^{-\tau}\left[\mathbb{1}+\sin \left(\rho^{\prime}\right)\left(\frac{\mathbf{R}}{\rho^{\prime}}\right)+\left(1-\cos \left(\rho^{\prime}\right)\right)\left(\frac{\mathbf{R}}{\rho^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

Similarly, without magneto-optical effects $\rho^{\prime}=q=\bar{b}=0, r=$ $h=\bar{b}^{2}=\left(\eta^{\prime}\right)^{2}, \vec{\mathbb{L}}=\mathbf{H}$, and we get the hyperbolic analogue:

$$
\mathbf{O}(s)=e^{-\tau}\left[\mathbb{1}+\operatorname{sh}\left(\eta^{\prime}\right)\left(\frac{\mathbf{H}}{\eta^{\prime}}\right)-\left(1-\operatorname{ch}\left(\eta^{\prime}\right)\right)\left(\frac{\mathbf{H}}{\eta^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

Finally, particularizing our result in Eq.(63) to constant propagation matrix, the evolution operator of LD85 is recovered.

### 4.2. Higher order terms of the Magnus expansion

Now consider again the Magnus expansion in Eq. (19) and let us explore what happens when including orders larger than one. To make things clearer, let us also rename the integration variables $s_{1}, s_{2}, \ldots, s_{n}$, as $s_{n}, s_{n-1}, \ldots, s_{1}$ in Eq. (15). Thus, $\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{2}$ gives:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{2}(s) & =-\frac{1}{2} \int_{s_{0}}^{s} d_{1} \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{1}} d_{2}\left[\mathbf{K}\left(s_{2}\right) \mathbf{K}\left(s_{1}\right)-\mathbf{K}\left(s_{1}\right) \mathbf{K}\left(s_{2}\right)\right]= \\
& =-\frac{1}{2} \int_{s_{0}}^{s} d_{2} \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{2}} d_{1}\left[\vec{\mathbb{L}}\left(s_{1}\right), \vec{\mathbb{L}}\left(s_{2}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Labelling the dependence on $s_{i}$ with a subindex $i$ and developing the commutator with Eqs. (48), involving the vector of basis matrices $\overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\vec{\mathbb{L}}_{1}, \vec{\mathbb{L}}_{2}\right]=\frac{i}{2}\left[\left(\vec{a}_{1} \times \vec{a}_{2}\right) \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}-\left(\vec{a}_{1}^{\prime} \times \vec{a}_{2}^{\prime}\right) \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}^{\tau}\right]=\Re e\left\{i \vec{a}_{1 s 2} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}\right\}=} \\
& =\left[\left(\vec{\eta}_{1} \times \vec{\eta}_{2}\right)-\left(\vec{\rho}_{1} \times \vec{\rho}_{2}\right)\right] \overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}-\left[\left(\vec{\eta}_{1} \times \vec{\rho}_{2}\right)+\left(\vec{\rho}_{1} \times \vec{\eta}_{2}\right)\right] \overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\vec{a}_{1 s 2}=\vec{a}_{1} \times \vec{a}_{2}$. Developing $\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{3}$ in a similar way:

$$
\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{3}(s)=-\frac{1}{4} \int_{s_{0}}^{s} d_{3} \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{3}} d_{2} \int_{s_{0}}^{s_{2}} d_{1}\left\{\left[\vec{\mathbb{L}}_{1}, \vec{\mathbb{L}}_{2}\right], \vec{\mathbb{L}}_{3}\right\}
$$

we obtain $\left\{\left[\vec{\mathbb{L}}_{1}, \vec{\mathbb{L}}_{2}\right], \vec{\mathbb{L}}_{3}\right\}=-\Re e\left\{\vec{a}_{(12) 3} \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}\right\}$ with $\vec{a}_{(12) 3}=$ $\left(\vec{a}_{1} \times \vec{a}_{2}\right) \times \vec{a}_{3}$. Moving each integral inward to the propagation vectors, and using Eq.(42) and Eqs. (48) again, the Magnus expansion can then be written by subspaces as:

$$
\boldsymbol{\Omega}^{\prime}(s)=\Re e[\vec{f}(s) \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{B}}]=\vec{f}_{w}(s) \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}+\vec{f}_{y}(s) \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathbf{G}}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{f}_{w}(s)=-\vec{w}_{1}(s)-\frac{1}{2} \vec{w}_{2}(s)+\frac{1}{4} \vec{w}_{3}(s)+\ldots \\
& \vec{f}_{y}(s)=-\vec{y}_{1}(s)-\frac{1}{2} \vec{y}_{2}(s)+\frac{1}{4} \vec{y}_{3}(s)+\ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \vec{w}_{1}(s)=\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \vec{\eta}(t) d t \quad ; \quad \vec{y}_{1}(s)=\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \vec{\rho}(t) d t \\
& \vec{w}_{2}(s)=-\int_{s_{0}}^{s}\left[\vec{y}_{1}(t) \times \vec{\eta}(t)+\vec{w}_{1}(t) \times \vec{\rho}(t)\right] d t \\

\end{aligned}
$$

The complexity of $\vec{f}_{w}(s)$ and $\vec{f}_{y}(s)$ increases in a non-obvious way when more terms are added to the Magnus expansion. Comparison of Eq. (74) with Eq. (45b) shows explicitly that, as expected, $\boldsymbol{\Omega}$ stays in the Lie algebra, having the same structure as the Lorentz matrix for any truncation of the Magnus expansion. As a result, the corresponding exponential evolution operator in Eq. (19) has the same form as Eq.(63), but now the quantities in Eqs. (60) are just obtained substituting $\vec{\eta}^{\prime}$ and $\vec{\rho}^{\prime}$ by $\vec{f}_{w}$ and $\vec{f}_{y}$, which contain integral corrections. Thus, the calculation Eq.(63) applied to higher orders is increasingly complicated by the presence of nested integrals of vector products, as those in Eqs. (76). We dont expect corrections beyond order 2 to be calculated efficiently by brute force. It is a matter of ongoing numerical investigation to find out how to calculate these integrals efficiently when extending our methods to higher orders of the expansion.

## 5. REFORMULATION OF THE INHOMOGENEOUS PROBLEM

The homogeneous evolution operator derived in the previous sections can be inserted into Eq. (6) to obtain a new family of numerical methods based on the Magnus expansion. However, the following issue motivates an alternative formulation for the inhomogeneous problem too. The inhomogeneous RTE:

$$
\mathbf{I}^{\prime}(s)=\mathbf{A}(s) \mathbf{I}(s)+\boldsymbol{\epsilon}(s) \quad ; \mathbf{I}(0)=\mathbf{I}_{0}
$$

with $\mathbf{A}(s)=-\mathbf{K}(s)$ can be solved with Eq. (6) using the full Magnus exponential as evolution operators in it. If we start considering Eq. (77) with a Magnus expansion to first order allowing for non-constant $\mathbf{A}(s)$, then:

$$
\mathbf{I}(s)=e^{\int_{0}^{s} \mathbf{A}(\tau) d \tau} \mathbf{I}_{0}+\int_{0}^{s} e^{\int_{0}^{s} \mathbf{A}(\tau) d \tau} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}(t) d t
$$

The problem here is that the calculation of the inhomogeneous integral with the nested integral in the inner exponent is costly and difficult to evaluate because we need two different sets of quadrature points for nested integrals changing in different intervals. To solve this problem, we have reformulated it.

### 5.1. Reformulating the case with constant properties

In order to introduce our method of solution for the general case, we first consider the simplest consistent system, given by Eq. (77) with both $\mathbf{A}$ and $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$ constant. It is easy to see that its solution can be written in terms of a matrix function $\boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A})$, both as

$$
\mathbf{I}(s)=e^{s \mathbf{A}} \mathbf{I}_{0}+\int_{0}^{s} e^{(s-t) \mathbf{A}} \boldsymbol{\epsilon} d t=e^{s \mathbf{A}} \mathbf{I}_{0}+s \boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A}) \boldsymbol{\epsilon}
$$

or as

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{I}(s) & =e^{s \mathbf{A}} \mathbf{I}_{0}+\left(e^{s \mathbf{A}}-\mathbb{1}\right) \mathbf{A}^{-1} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}=e^{s \mathbf{A}}\left(\mathbf{I}_{0}+\mathbf{A}^{-1} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}\right)-\mathbf{A}^{-1} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}= \\
& =\mathbf{I}_{0}+s \boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A})\left(\mathbf{A} \mathbf{I}_{0}+\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we define $\boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A})$ in several equivalent ways:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A}) & =\frac{1}{s} \int_{0}^{s} e^{(s-t) \mathbf{A}} d t=\frac{1}{s} \int_{0}^{s} e^{s \mathbf{A}} d t= \\
& =\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(s \mathbf{A})^{n}}{(n+1)!}= \\
& =\left(e^{s \mathbf{A}}-\mathbb{1}\right)(s \mathbf{A})^{-1}=\left(\equiv \frac{e^{s}-\mathbb{1}}{s}\right) \\
& =\int_{0}^{1} e^{\xi s \mathbf{A}} d \xi
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (81a) shows the relation of $\boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A})$ with Eq. (79), while Eq. (81b) shows its relation with the exponential

$$
e^{s \mathbf{A}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{(s \mathbf{A})^{n}}{n!}
$$

Alternatively, Eq. (81c) gives an inefficient way of calculating $\boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A})$ inverting a matrix, but also points out the relation with the generatrix function of the inverse of the Magnus expansion itself (see Eq. (14)). Finally, eq. (81d) gives an efficient integral definition in terms of a parameter $\xi$.

The second key point of our method of solution is the realization that the Eq. (77) with both $\mathbf{A}$ and $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$ constant is equivalent to a $5 \times 5$ homogeneous system

$$
\frac{d}{d s}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\mathbf{I}(s) \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\mathbf{A} & \boldsymbol{\epsilon} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\mathrm{T}} & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\mathbf{I}(s) \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

with $\mathbf{I}(0)=\mathbf{I}_{0}$, and whose new $5 \times 5$ propagation matrix $\mathcal{A}_{5}$ contains $\mathbf{A} \equiv \mathbf{A}_{4 \times 4}$. Correspondingly, from Eq. (4), the solution in Eq. (79) must be equivalent to the 5D solution:

$$
\mathbf{I}_{5}(s)=e^{s \mathcal{A}_{5}} \mathbf{I}_{5,0}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
e^{s \mathbf{A}} & s \boldsymbol{\phi}(s \mathbf{A}) \boldsymbol{\epsilon} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\mathrm{T}} & 0
\end{array}\right) \mathbf{I}_{5,0}
$$

with $\mathbf{I}_{5,0} \equiv \mathbf{I}_{5}(0)=\left(\mathbf{I}_{0}, 1\right)^{\mathrm{T}}$. Eq. (84) tells us that the inhomogeneous solution for $\mathcal{A}_{5}$ constant can be written as a $5 \times 5$ evolution operator containing both the corresponding $4 \times 4$ evolution operator and a special product involving $\boldsymbol{\phi}$. Let us now apply this to the general case.

### 5.2. Reformulating the general case with arbitrary variations

The method that we propose consists in extending by one the dimension of the inhomogeneous problem to convert it in a five-dimensional homogeneous one, and thus solve it with the Magnus expansion again. Namely, Eq. (78) is equivalent to a $5 \times 5$ homogeneous system

$$
\frac{d}{d s}\left(\begin{array}{c}
\mathbf{I}(s) \\
1
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\mathbf{A}(s) & \boldsymbol{\epsilon}(s) \\
\mathbf{0}^{\mathrm{T}} & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{c}
\mathbf{I}(s) \\
1
\end{array}\right)
$$

with $\mathbf{I}_{5,0} \equiv \mathbf{I}_{5}(0)=\left(\mathbf{I}_{0}, 1\right)^{\mathrm{T}}$, and where again we call $\mathbf{I}_{5}(\mathrm{~s})$ to the solution vector of unknowns and $\mathcal{A}_{5}(\mathrm{~s})$ to the new propagation matrix containing the original $\mathbf{A}(s)=-\mathbf{K}(s)$. Being homogeneous, this system can be solved applying the Magnus expansion to $\mathcal{A}_{5}(s)$. We do this first considering only $\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{1}$ in the Magnus expansion, to keep consistency with

the evolution operator that we derived in the previous section. Thus, we have to calculate:

$$
\mathbf{O}_{5}(\mathrm{~s})=e^{\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \mathcal{A}_{h}(t) d t}=e^{\mathcal{A}_{5}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\overline{\mathcal{A}}_{5}^{n}}{n!}
$$

where the overbars mean integration hereafter:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\overline{\mathcal{A}}_{5}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\overline{\mathbf{A}} & \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}} & 0
\end{array}\right) \\
\overline{\mathbf{A}}=-\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \mathbf{K}(t) d t \quad ; \quad \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}=\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \boldsymbol{\epsilon}(t) d t
\end{gathered}
$$

These integrals contain the six ray-path scalar integrals of Eq.(60b) $\eta_{k}^{\prime}$ and $\rho_{k}^{\prime}(k=1,2,3)$, and the four ones of $\epsilon_{k}^{\prime}(k=$ $0,1,2,3)$. Since the powers of $\overline{\mathcal{A}}_{5}$ show the simple general form

$$
\overline{\mathcal{A}}_{5}^{\prime}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\overline{\mathbf{A}}^{n} & \overline{\mathbf{A}}^{n-1} \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}} & 0
\end{array}\right)
$$

all terms in Eq. (86) can be readily resummed to obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{O}_{5}(\mathrm{~s}) & =\left(\begin{array}{cc}
e^{\overline{\mathbf{A}}} & {\left[\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\overline{\mathbf{A}}^{n}}{n+1!}\right] \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}} & 1
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
e^{\overline{\mathbf{A}}} & \boldsymbol{\phi}(\overline{\mathbf{A}}) \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}} & 1
\end{array}\right) \\
& =\mathbb{1}_{5}+\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\phi(\overline{\mathbf{A}}) \overline{\mathbf{A}} & \phi(\overline{\mathbf{A}}) \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}} \\
\mathbf{0}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}} & 0
\end{array}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have used the definition of $\phi$ in Eq. (81b). Inserting the above equivalent expressions into the general solution $\mathbf{I}_{5}(s)=\mathbf{O}_{5}(\mathrm{~s}) \mathbf{I}_{5,0}$, and taking the $4 \times 4$ subspace, we find:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{I}(s) & =e^{\overline{\mathbf{A}}} \mathbf{I}_{0}+\boldsymbol{\phi}(\overline{\mathbf{A}}) \overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}}= \\
& =\mathbf{I}_{0}+\boldsymbol{\phi}(\overline{\mathbf{A}})(\overline{\mathbf{A}} \mathbf{I}_{0}+\overline{\boldsymbol{\epsilon}})
\end{aligned}
$$

which reduces to Eqs. (79) and (80) when $\mathbf{A}$ and $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$ are constant.
What has happened in Eqs. (90)? The inhomogeneous formal integral that has always characterized the radiative transfer solution (e.g., in Eq. 6 or 78) has been absorbed into an algebraic expression. Eq. (90) replaces it with the product of an integrated emissivity vector and a special function of an integrated propagation matrix. We explain this by noting that solving the $4 \times 4$ inhomogeneous problem via the Magnus solution to the $5 \times 5$ homogeneous problem is like treating the emissivity translations in Poincaré space as higher-dimensional rotations described by the $5 \times 5$ Magnus algebra. Thus, Eqs. (90) offers a novel approach to solving the radiative transfer problem.
This can be extended to higher orders. Eq. (89a) shows that the algebra of the 5D propagation matrix is such that the 4D subspace containing the 4D homogeneous evolution operator is always independent on the inhomogeneous part of the system containing $\phi$ and $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$. This implies that if we extend the Magnus expansion to higher orders, we can always continue using the corresponding evolution operator because the only thing that changes is how the function $\phi$ is combined with $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$. For instance, adding $\boldsymbol{\Omega}_{2}$ to the Magnus expansion we would be adding a term of the kind of Eq.(72), but with the commutator :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& {\left[\mathcal{A}_{5}\left(s_{1}\right), \mathcal{A}_{5}\left(s_{2}\right)\right]=\mathcal{A}_{5}\left(s_{1}\right) \mathcal{A}_{5}\left(s_{2}\right)-\mathcal{A}_{5}\left(s_{2}\right), \mathcal{A}_{5}\left(s_{1}\right)=} \\
& =\left(\begin{array}{cc}
{\left[\mathbf{A}\left(s_{1}\right), \mathbf{A}\left(s_{2}\right)\right]} & \mathbf{A}\left(s_{1}\right) \boldsymbol{\epsilon}\left(s_{2}\right)-\mathbf{A}\left(s_{2}\right) \boldsymbol{\epsilon}\left(s_{1}\right) \\
\mathbf{0}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}} & 0
\end{array}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Here, the $4 \times 4$ subspace is preserved, containing a commutator similar to that in the l.h.s. Thus, after integrating and
exponentiating, the new solution will have the new evolution operator (now including $\Omega_{2}$ ) and a composition of matrixvector products between $\boldsymbol{\phi}$ and integrals of $\mathbf{A}$ and $\boldsymbol{\epsilon}$. We will have to find the right balance between more general theoretical description (higher order in Magnus) and more efficient computational representation (higher numerical order of integration and fastest calculation).

### 5.3. Calculation of $\phi$ : introducing the inhomogeneous evolution operator

An advantage of our approach is that $\boldsymbol{\phi}(\overline{\mathbf{A}})$ in Eq. (90a) can be calculated analytically. Namely, applying Eq. (81d)

$$
\phi(-\overline{\mathbf{K}})=\int_{0}^{1} e^{-\int_{s_{0}}^{s} \bar{\varepsilon} \mathbf{K}(t) d \bar{\varepsilon}} d \bar{\varepsilon}=\int_{0}^{1} D(t, \bar{\varepsilon}) d \bar{\varepsilon}
$$

we see that $\phi$ is obtained by integrating our evolution operator Eq. (63) along a parameter $\bar{\varepsilon}$ assigned to every matrix component of $\overline{\mathbf{K}}$, i.e. to every $\eta^{\prime}$ and $\rho^{\prime}$ in Eqs. (60b) and in $\mathbb{Z}, \mathbb{Z}^{2}$. However, $\bar{\varepsilon}$ only survives inside the exponential and trigonometrical expressions because its dependence cancels out when multiplying every matrix (containing $\eta$ 's and $\rho$ 's to the same power of the matrix ${ }^{18}$ ) by its accompanying factor in $f_{0}, f_{1 a}, f_{1 b}, f_{2}$. This is easy to see by writing (67) as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{O}(s, \bar{\varepsilon})= & e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \operatorname{ch}(\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) \cdot\left(\frac{\bar{\delta}^{2} \bar{\imath}+\overline{\bar{\varepsilon}}^{2}}{\bar{\delta}^{2}+\bar{\delta}^{2}}\right)+e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \cos (\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) \cdot\left(\frac{\bar{\delta}^{2} \bar{\imath}-\overline{\bar{\varepsilon}}^{2}}{\bar{\delta}^{2}+\bar{\delta}^{2}}\right)- \\
& -e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \operatorname{sh}(\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) \cdot\left(\frac{\bar{\delta} \bar{\varepsilon}+\bar{\delta} \bar{\varepsilon}}{\bar{\delta}^{2}+\bar{\delta}^{2}}\right)+e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \sin (\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) \cdot\left(\frac{\bar{\delta} \bar{\varepsilon}-\bar{\delta} \bar{\varepsilon}}{\bar{\delta}^{2}+\bar{\delta}^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Then, in solving for Eq. (92), only the following integrals appear. Integrating (e.g., with Gradshteyn et al. 2015), and defining the ratios $\bar{\rho}=\bar{\delta} / \tau$ and $\bar{\rho}=\bar{\delta} / \tau$, we obtain:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \bar{c}_{1}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \operatorname{ch}(\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) d \bar{\varepsilon}=\frac{(1-\bar{c})-\bar{\rho} \bar{s}}{\tau\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)} \Leftrightarrow \quad \bar{c}=e^{-\tau} \operatorname{ch}(\bar{b}) \\
& \bar{c}_{1}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \cos (\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) d \bar{\varepsilon}=\frac{(1-\bar{c})+\bar{\rho} \bar{s}}{\tau\left(1+\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)} \Leftrightarrow \quad \bar{c}=e^{-\tau} \cos (\bar{b}) \\
& \bar{s}_{1}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \operatorname{sh}(\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) d \bar{\varepsilon}=\frac{\bar{\rho}(1-\bar{c})-\bar{s}}{\tau\left(1-\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)} \Leftrightarrow \quad \bar{s}=e^{-\tau} \operatorname{sh}(\bar{b}) \\
& \bar{s}_{1}=\int_{0}^{1} e^{-\tau \bar{\varepsilon}} \sin (\bar{h} \bar{\varepsilon}) d \bar{\varepsilon}=\frac{\bar{\rho}(1-\bar{c})-\bar{s}}{\tau\left(1+\bar{\rho}^{2}\right)} \Leftrightarrow \quad \bar{s}=e^{-\tau} \sin (\bar{b})
\end{aligned}
$$

where we have signified that $\bar{c}, \bar{c}, \bar{s}, \bar{s}$ (on the right) has been transformed to $\bar{c}_{1}, \bar{c}_{1}, \bar{s}_{1}, \bar{s}_{1}$ (on the left). Since the rest of the homogeneous evolution operator (67) remains unchanged, the result to Eq. (92) is a strictly analogous operator with the same algebraic structure: it depends on the same matrices and is multiplied by similar scalar functions $f_{0}, f_{1 a}, f_{1 b}, f_{2}$ from (64), but now with the substitution shown above. Hence, in a boast of creativity, we refer to $\phi$ as the inhomogeneous evolution operator. Since the same Lorentz matrices built from integrated optical profiles can be reused for both operators, and as the formal solution (90a) involves only two matrix-vector products, the computational cost of our analytical solution is quiet contained. Note also that the full development always remains mathematically exact up to the order chosen for truncating the Magnus expansion.
